review.title: Evaluation Measures for Hierarchical Classification: a unified view and novel approaches
review.abstract: Hierarchical classification addresses the problem of classifying items into a hierarchy of classes. An important issue in hierarchical classification is the evaluation of different classification algorithms, which is complicated by the hierarchical relations among the classes. Several evaluation measures have been proposed for hierarchical classification using the hierarchy in different ways. This paper studies the problem of evaluation in hierarchical classification by analyzing and abstracting the key components of the existing performance measures. It also proposes two alternative generic views of hierarchical evaluation and introduces two corresponding novel measures. The proposed measures, along with the state-of-the art ones, are empirically tested on three large datasets from the domain of text classification. The empirical results illustrate the undesirable behavior of existing approaches and how the proposed methods overcome most of these methods across a range of cases.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 130 6.68 02Hierarchical Classification deals with the problem of classifying items into a hierarchy of classes. An important issue of hierarchical classification is the evaluation of different classification algorithms, complicated by the hierarchical relationships between classes. Several benchmarks for hierarchical classification have been proposed, using the hierarchy in different ways. In this paper, the problem of evaluation in hierarchical classification is examined by analyzing and abstracting the key components of the existing performance benchmarks. In addition, two alternative generic views of hierarchical evaluation are proposed and two corresponding new benchmarks are introduced. Together with the state-of-the-art measures, the proposed measures are empirically tested on three large data sets in the field of text classification. Empirical results illustrate the undesirable behavior of existing approaches and how the proposed methods overcome most of these methods in a number of cases.

sections.text: Performance MeasuresThis section introduces a new framework within which HC performance metrics can be described and characterized. First, the supporting notation is defined, then the general evaluation requirements are presented and discussed, based on interesting problems encountered in hierarchical classification, and then the presentation of the proposed framework, which is used in further sections to describe and analyze the metrics.

sections.text: In classification tasks, the training set is typically referred to as S = {(xi, yi)} ni = 1, where xi is the attribute vector of instance i and yi C is the set of classes to which the instance belongs, where C = {c1,..., cK}.Unlike flat classification, where classes are considered unrelated, classes are organized into taxonomies. Taxonomies are usually either trees in which nodes (classes) each have a single parent, or guided acyclic graphs (DAGs) in which nodes can have multiple parents; see Figures 1 (a) and 1 (b), respectively. In some cases, hierarchies can also be cyclic graphs. sections.heading: 4 Empirical Study
sections.text: In this section we apply different evaluation yardsticks to the predictions of the systems participating in the Large Scale Hierarchical Text Classification Pascal Challenges of 2011 (LSHTC2) and 2012 (LSHTC3). The aim of this section is to examine, using real data and systems, to what extent the performance ranking of systems is influenced by the choice of flat and hierarchical evaluation yardsticks as well as by the type of hierarchical yardsticks used. In the first subsection we present the data sets we use, in the second subsection we discuss the evaluation yardsticks contained in the comparison, and in the last subsection we discuss the results of the study. In the third section we have shown that in certain cases some measures behave more desirably than others. In this section we show that the differences between methods also influence the evaluation yardsticks in practice.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we investigated the problem of assessing the performance of hierarchical classification methods. Specifically, this paper abstracted and presented the main points of existing performance measures. We proposed grouping the methods into a) pair-based and b) set-based. Measures in the former group attempt to assign each prediction to a true class and measure its distance. In contrast, set-based measures use the hierarchical relationships to expand the sets of predicted and true labels, and then use set operations, such as symmetric difference and intersections, on the extended label sets. To model pair-based measurements, we introduced a novel framework based on flow networks, while providing a framework for set-up measures based on defined operations. Thus, outstanding features of these measures are emphasized and addressed under a common formalism.Another contribution of this paper was the suggestion of two measures (one for each group) that address multiple measures in a hierarchical manner.
